It meets head-on the current concerns about the morality of the markets in the midst of corporate scandals and falling share prices. The author, Younkins, puts the moral case for capitalism and says that the capitalist system is good not only for the wallet but also for the soul. Capitalism, he writes:

quote.para: ... not only can generate enormous wealth but can also create an environment in which morality and virtue can flourish ... and that morality is the ethic of individual responsibility and accountable free choices.

speech.para: In fact, he makes a pretty strong case for free markets, for free trade, for the corporation and, indeed, for business as a noble calling.

This government has recognised that there has to be a balance between breaking the shackles that have, until recently, held down our national living standards, our employment levels and our entrepreneurial spirit, and an appropriate level of state regulation. In that context, the government is entitled to pride itself on what it has achieved in creating an internationally competitive tax environment in Australia and drawing the attention of and investment from those outside our borders.

We pride ourselves on reducing company tax from 36 per cent to 30 per cent, halving the capital gains tax burden for individuals, simplifying and extending the existing small business capital gains tax rollover relief and retirement exemptions—and I could go on. But we take pleasure in supporting this bill which takes these reforms further in four parts: a consolidation regime, a simplified imputations system, value shifting and loss integrity, and relief for corporate demergers. The consolidation regime reform was first flagged in the tax reform proposals of 1998. Consolidation in this context refers to the concept where companies in a group which are wholly owned and which satisfy certain other conditions may elect to be treated as a single entity for tax purposes. Consolidation represents a much more comprehensive system which will eventually replace the current grouping rules.

In order to deal with outstanding matters associated with the New Business Tax System (Consolidation) Bill, which was passed by the parliament in the last hours of the budget session, this legislation introduces cost-setting rules for the formation of consolidation groups, and those rules have implications for the basic case rules where a single entity enters into an existing consolidated group. There are a number of other amendments but, given the time, I will not go into them. Regarding the simplified imputation system, the legislation before the House makes consequential amendments to those provisions of the tax law known as the exempting and former exempting company provisions, further to the imputation bill that was also passed by the parliament at the same time as the consolidation bill.

I now turn to the issue of value shifting and loss integrity. Unlike the two previous areas of interest, these particular amendments are not consequential. Instead, this measure will introduce a general value-shifting regime applying principally to interests in controlled companies and trusts that are not consolidated. The existing capital gains laws will be strengthened by this measure. Furthermore, under the loss integrity reforms, assets will be valued globally in calculating unrealised losses, thereby further reducing compliance costs.

Finally, I turn to the subject of demerger relief. Demergers are a form of structural readjustment for corporations in which a corporate or trust group splits into two or more entities or groups. In such cases, the underlying owners of the head entity directly control the demerged entities or groups. The bill provides for a capital gains tax rollover of a head entity of a demerger group; a capital gains tax exemption for certain capital gains or losses made by the members of a demerger group where at least 80 per cent of the demerger group's interests in a demerger subsidiary are transferred to the owners of the head entity; and an exemption from the existing dividend rules for the head entity's owners, subject to an integrity rule. These rollovers and exemptions apply to demergers as from 1 July this year.

This particular reform will ensure that tax considerations are not a barrier to this particular form of corporate restructure. The House would be aware that corporate Australia awaits this particular reform. In particular, the shareholders of WMC will have the opportunity, should this legislation pass, to vote on the planned split-up of WMC—for the tax relief will enable that company to move ahead, finally, with the planned spin-off of its alumina business—in the face of a hostile takeover proposal from its US aluminium partner, Alcoa. Without the tax relief, potential acquirers of the spin-off businesses would be lumped with a capital gains tax bill—in that case, estimated at up to $1 billion. In concluding, I point out that all the reforms contained in this bill are improvements to business taxation in Australia and, accordingly, I commend the bill to the House.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —in reply—I would like to thank the members for Fraser, Curtin and Mitchell for their speeches in relation to the New Business Tax System (Consolidation, Value Shifting, Demergers and Other Measures) Bill 2002. I am hopeful, given the importance of the measures contained in this bill to all sectors of the business community, that the government will receive the support of the House and, indeed, the other place in relation to this particular legislation. However, prior to the vote taking place, I would like to take the opportunity to sum up the tenor of issues raised during the debate on these measures. I will also be discussing some amendments the government will be moving in relation to this bill in respect of the demerger measures.

speech.para: The member for Fraser broadly supported the principles contained in this legislation, and I thank him for that on behalf of the government. In his speech, he referred to value-shifting variations from the Ralph recommendations and also the compliance costs. Notwithstanding that, he indicated his support. The government does welcome the support of the member for Fraser for this very important integrity measure which is complementary to consolidation. The general value shifting rules were modified, following discussions with business, and the modifications address deficiencies in the current tax treatment of value shifting and provide comparable value-shifting integrity for entities outside consolidation to that achieved within consolidation. The compliance costs associated with this measure are a consequence of business coming to terms with the new legislation only, and no new notification or specific compliance costs associated with this measure are foreseen.

In his speech, the member for Fraser accused the government of backing down on integrity measures. I just want to point out to him and to reassure him that the revenue protection measures are not a backdown but a proactive move by the government to prevent unintended tax benefits to groups during the transition to consolidation. The member for Fraser also referred generally to taxation legislation and claimed that the devil is in the detail. With respect to the concerns expressed by the member relating to implementation, I would note the extraordinary level of consultation on these measures. The purpose of this consultation is to ensure a smooth implementation of these measures and no surprises in the measures. The government is committed to maintaining the momentum of tax reform, and the timetable for reform was outlined by the Assistant Treasurer in May this year. This timetable was welcomed by businesses and provides greater certainty and a manageable pace of reform.

The member for Fraser referred to the fact that this legislation is being brought before the parliament in a number of tranches. On passage of this bill, the consolidation package, combined with the government's detailed press release of 27 June this year on revenue protection measures, will be sufficient to enable taxpayers to determine whether to consolidate. Some further legislation will be introduced in the spring session, giving effect to the government's press release on the revenue protection measures. The legislation will also cover consequential and technical amendments and aspects of the regime affecting relatively few taxpayers—that is, life insurance and further international aspects.

The member for Fraser, who has now returned to the chamber, mentioned complexity. Consolidation is a very significant tax reform for Australian corporate groups and will assist in the simplification of business structures, reduce ongoing compliance and administration costs, improve business efficiency and strengthen the integrity of the tax system by preventing inappropriate outcomes being generated through intragroup dealings. The government has given all businesses more time to prepare for consolidation. To support this extension of time, the government has agreed to a request from small business that existing grouping rules be retained for an additional 12 months following the commencement of consolidation. I am pleased, in particular, to reassure the honourable member for Mitchell in view of his comments. Groups are able to elect to consolidate at the time they lodge their first consolidated tax return. This effectively allows up to 18 months or more for taxpayers to decide whether to consolidate, with effect from 1 July 2002, and to complete the necessary arrangements.

Transitional concessions that allow groups to retain existing asset cost bases and use certain transferred losses over three years have also been extended and will now be available for groups that consolidate before 1 July 2004. The government, as I mentioned previously, has consulted extensively with the business community. The tax office has also released extensive guideline documents to assist business to better understand and prepare for the measure. It also ought to be recognised that consolidation is optional, it is not compulsory and will generally only be relevant to the relatively few small businesses that operate through corporate group structures.

The member for Mitchell outlined benefits to businesses arising from consolidation. His speech is certainly welcomed. There will be very considerable compliance savings to consolidated groups from consolidation after a group is formed. Consolidation will assist simplification of business structures and reduce ongoing compliance and administration costs.

The bill introduces a number of important business tax reform measures which originate from the recommendations of the Ralph Review of Business Taxation in A tax system redesigned. The bill contains the second tranche of consolidation legislation, introduces a general value shifting regime for groups that do not consolidate, introduces tax relief for corporate and trust demergers and provides consequential amendments to the simplified imputation system. Extensive consultation has taken place. I am very pleased to advise the House that the business community very strongly supports what the government is doing. The consolidation regime delivered by this bill represents one of the most significant changes to the taxation of corporate groups and will ensure greater flexibility and reduce ongoing compliance costs for Australian businesses as well as address concerns in relation to the integrity of our tax system.

This bill, in conjunction with the first tranche of the consolidation legislation which has since received royal assent, ensures there is sufficient information for businesses to be confident in determining whether to enter consolidation and it provides the mechanisms to do so. In particular, the measures dealing with the cost setting rules and concessional transitional cost setting rules for groups forming a consolidated group are critical to such an assessment. The bill also introduces important measures dealing with some international aspects of consolidation, including the transfer and pooling of group foreign tax credits and attribution accounts maintained by entities with interests in controlled foreign companies or foreign income funds on both entry and exit from a consolidated group. The general value shifting regime introduced by this bill represents an important integrity measure designed to prevent the manipulation of tax rules by shifting value between assets by closely held entities that are not part of the same consolidated group. This new regime is complementary to the consolidation regime and will reproduce the structural value shifting integrity achieved by the consolidation regime to those groups outside consolidation.

The final important business tax measure in this bill introduces provisions to provide tax relief for corporate or trust demergers. The tax relief will apply to only genuine demergers and is achieved by requiring underlying ownership to be maintained pre and post a merger and requiring the head entity to demerge at least 80 per cent of its ownership in the demerging entity. Providing tax relief for demergers will increase business efficiency by allowing greater flexibility in restructuring a business and ensuring tax considerations are not an impediment to such restructures. This will provide an overall benefit to the economy and enhance the competitiveness of Australia's business sector through greater opportunities to increase shareholder value by creating more efficient business structures.

The demerging amendments proposed by the government will facilitate the provision of tax relief for demergers. The main changes proposed by the government include the recognition of an additional method by which a demerger may occur, the provision of more flexibility in identifying the appropriate head entity of a demerger group, the provision of a new limited exemption to the maintenance of underlying ownership requirement to recognise certain financial instruments issued by a listed public company or listed widely held trust. A number of the amendments are as a result of business representations after the introduction of this bill and as part of the ongoing consultation process. Other amendments are of a technical and clarifying nature.

The member for Fraser referred to the revenue implications of demergers. As reported in the 2002-03 budget, a reliable estimate of the review impact of the demerger provisions cannot be provided. This is because there is no reliable information of demerger activity tax base issues and a number of possible positive and negative impacts on revenue. While there is some expected revenue cost associated with the deferral of capital gains tax on the demerger event, examples of positive impacts on revenue include shareholders selling shares they own in the demerged entity earlier than otherwise and benefits flowing from efficiency gains. There were a number of other issues raised which I would have liked to have addressed in this particular debate. But, given the time and the fact that the adjournment of the House is approaching and the desire to have the House pass this legislation and also deal with the consideration in detail prior to 7.30, I will desist from that temptation. I would, therefore, commend the legislation to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

Mr SLIPPER

speech.para: In the light of submissions made by industry commenting on the provisions of the bill providing tax relief for demergers, the government proposes to make a number of minor amendments directed at clarifying and improving the demergers legislation. These amendments include: allowing greater flexibility in identifying an appropriate head entity of a demerger group—amendments (3), (4) and (5); providing additional flexibility in the way a demerger may occur—amendments (8), (9), (10) and (24); introducing an additional exception into the requirement to maintain underlying ownership for certain hybrid—that is, part debt, part equity—instruments that have a reset clause subject to a 10 per cent de minimus rule—amendment (30); and a number of technical amendments to ensure that the demergers measure operates in the way that is intended—amendments (1), (2), (6), (7), (11) to (23), (25) to (29) and (31) to (53). In view of the time, I do not intend to delay the House further by expanding any more on these amendments, but they will apply to demergers happening on or after 1 July this year, coinciding with the commencement date of the legislation. I am particularly pleased to commend government amendments (1) to (53) to the House.

We will certainly allow them to pass without opposition in this chamber and then we will scrutinise them in more detail in what we hope will be a Senate committee consideration of the bill shortly.

talk.start.para: —The events of the past week involving the Bulldogs rugby league club are a sad chapter in the history of that fine game. The sport itself has been brought into disrepute by a small number of individuals who placed personal gain ahead of their duty to the game of rugby league and the thousands of Bulldogs supporters. Those supporters can rightly feel betrayed by the actions of a few. So, too, can residents of Liverpool in my electorate where the promise of world-class sporting and entertainment venues in our area is now under a cloud. But where does the blame lie? If you go fishing for the culprits, you will find that it always leads back to one creature. Like the tentacles on a giant squid, scam after scam leads back to one head—to one giant squid. I will call him Mr Calamari.

speech.para: With one tentacle Mr Calamari reached into the Oasis project in Liverpool. He acted as a kind of project manager and allocated tenders for the construction work. Through his associated company, he contracted work out for which he was reimbursed by the Bulldogs' Sports and Community Foundation. One tenderer for work was surprised when told by Mr Calamari that he should give a higher quote and his tender would still be accepted. He did in fact get the contract, but has since found that he was paid for only part of the total sum quoted. He is out of pocket by more than $100,000 but, as far as he is aware, Mr Calamari's company was fully reimbursed. The practice of getting two quotes from subcontractors is a common way in which head contractors can extract secret commissions from project owners.

Mr Calamari's activities with Oasis also included responsibility for its financial arrangements and public relations. Each of these tentacles may have been just as lucrative as skimming secret commissions from subcontractors. On top of that, Mr Calamari is reputed to have received a salary of $450,000 a year for his work at Oasis. Mr Calamari also has tentacles into real estate. He is reported to lease part of the building he owns in Burwood to the Bulldogs for a rental of $120,000 a year. Acting without board approval, he undertook to purchase units at Caloundra in Queensland on behalf of the Bulldogs. He wanted to sign up for a price of $200,000 for units valued at $155,000. I wonder who was going to pocket the difference?

Mr Calamari's tentacles also reach into the area of sports management. He is reputed to receive 10 per cent of the sponsorship money from Bulldogs' sponsors: building company ADCO and building suppliers NTG and Clipsal. That is not a bad little earner, and there might even have been a little deal on the side to get contracts at Oasis. The tentacles also reach into sports merchandising. A fake order, on Bulldogs letterhead, for $211,000 worth of Nike style jackets has led to the supplier chasing one of Mr Calamari's companies for payment, and Nike is reported to be investigating the use of its logo.

What I have described is probably just the tip of the iceberg. Mr Calamari's tentacles extend into many dark corners, not the least of which was making the under-the-table payments to Bulldogs players. And he has one other tentacle to watch. The story of the Bulldogs' salary cap breaches was broken by the Sydney Morning Herald, and this happened after his dealings with the Bulldogs were terminated last June. While the Herald seems to know a lot about the other players in this drama, Mr Calamari is portrayed as an innocent bystander. While its sister paper the Australian Financial Review details his sordid dealings, the Herald merely describes him as a controversial businessman. It is time to blow the whistle on the whistleblower. Mr Calamari is, of course, Mr Al Constantinidis, and it seems that his tentacles reach all the way to Sydney's Broadway.

talk.start.para: —I rise to continue the speech I commenced in the House last night. You may recall that I highlighted the huge impact that meningococcal disease has had not only throughout the world but also in my electorate of Dobell on the Central Coast. In recent times, we have tragically lost two young children to this terrible disease—namely, Stephen Sanig and Rebecca Calverley. They both lived in my electorate. I should emphasise that, despite the fact that their parents, on arriving at the hospital, were already convinced that their children had meningococcal disease, diagnosis and subsequent treatment did not come soon enough to save their children. What concerns me is that various studies—including those of the state government of Victoria—on the treatment of meningococcal disease stress that antibiotic therapy should not be delayed while initiating or awaiting the results of diagnostic tests. While some in the medical profession prefer not to administer antibiotics until they are sure of what they are dealing with, perhaps in the case of such a potentially fatal disease presumption should prevail and therapy be initiated at the earliest opportunity.

speech.para: Previously, I spoke of the important work being performed by the Meningococcal Association of Australia and of how I recently attended the launch of their special educational brochure that is designed to assist parents by alerting them to the symptoms of meningococcal disease. I would like to remind the House that this brochure is of tremendous value to parents in their fight to protect their children against the threat of this disease.

It is important to point out that the two predominant strains of meningococcal disease are referred to as B and C. It is also important to point out that, while there is still no vaccine for the B strain, around two-thirds of those infected by the C strain are more likely to die. So it is highly appropriate that the government, for the moment, is concentrating on administering the C vaccine through its program, and I applaud the Howard government for that. While the vaccine is in limited supply, I am comforted by the knowledge that the Minister for Health and Ageing, Senator Kay Patterson, will expand the meningococcal C vaccination program as soon as more vaccine is produced. Fortunately, two new suppliers have just completed the registration process through the Therapeutic Goods Administration, and this will help to ease the worldwide shortage of this much-needed vaccine.

I also point out that, contrary to many views on meningococcal disease, the germ itself cannot survive outside the human body for more than a few seconds and that you cannot catch meningococcal disease from water supplies, buildings or factories. The disease is commonly transmitted by sharing saliva, and I warn all parents—particularly those of school-age children—that, although the disease is difficult to spread, they should make sure that their children do not share their drink bottles with others and that they should discourage any other practice that might assist in the transfer of saliva.

Finally, I would encourage all members to do whatever they can in their respective electorates to minimise the spread of this dreadful disease and to support the Meningococcal Association of Australia in their efforts to alert all parents to the symptoms of the disease so that early diagnosis is more likely. As I am not a member of the medical profession, it is not really my place to advise on such matters. I would ask those who are to consider assuming the worst when confronted with symptoms that suggest the onset of meningococcal disease and to administer antibiotic therapy as soon as possible. Bear in mind that the photograph featured on the front of that brochure is that of seven-year-old Stephen Sanig, a little boy who had everything to live for but who lost his life just 14 hours after the onset of a fever.

talk.start.para: —I rise to talk about the importance of Western Sydney and, in doing so, to reject some of the unfounded criticism of the performance and commitment of the New South Wales government with respect to Western Sydney made by the member for Lindsay earlier this week. Western Sydney is the third largest region in Australia. It is a region that continues to experience significant levels of growth, but it is also a region facing major challenges in that it has a number of areas of considerable disadvantage. I believe that Western Sydney today is typical of many regions across the nation that are the result of urban sprawl and the expansion of our major cities and that are now somewhat of a heartbeat for the cities themselves. As we all appreciate, Australia is facing a significant backlog of infrastructure development—be it arterial roads in our capital cities, schools, hospitals, affordable housing or public transport links.

speech.para: For the member for Lindsay to stand in this House and condemn the New South Wales government as failing to address vital infrastructure backlog in the region is an exercise in blatant hypocrisy. It is not the role of state and local government alone. It is not good enough for the member for Lindsay to pass the buck and to dismiss the role of the Commonwealth in providing such infrastructure. The community of Western Sydney, an area in which I mix on a frequent basis, requires that all tiers of government put aside their so-called differences and historical competition and work out a concerted strategy based on cooperation at local, state and federal levels. As we all appreciate, good infrastructure planning and development requires the cooperation of all levels of government. They must work together to achieve the best outcomes for all regions across Australia, for both urban and regional communities.

I believe the member for Lindsay should step back and take stock of the total lack of interest from her frontbench in infrastructure development, particularly from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, when it comes to the issue of the future of Western Sydney. The minister for transport's commitment to transport infrastructure development is conditional on how many votes he thinks can be bought with respect to a commitment to a particular infrastructure project. For example, the people of Western Sydney should not forget that, when it came to the issue of the national highway and the Western Sydney Orbital, the minister imposed on Western Sydney a road toll. Alternatively, when it came to the Scoresby Freeway project in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, not a Commonwealth responsibility but a state responsibility in association with the Commonwealth, it was fully funded by an agreement between the Victorian and the Commonwealth governments. So much for the commitment by the Commonwealth government to infrastructure needs in Western Sydney.

If the member for Lindsay is so concerned about transport infrastructure development, lifestyle and access to public transport, let us have a look at the performance of her own government. Take, for example, its current policy position. Firstly, there is no mention of public transport in the AusLink plan—the minister's supposed all-encompassing transport infrastructure plan. I would have thought access to public transport is about lifestyle. Buses get a raw deal under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. There is still a GST on public transport. Current tax arrangements favour the increased use of company vehicles, which account for about 40 per cent of traffic during peak hours. Congestion clearly contributes to lifestyle. We have a national cycling strategy that the minister for transport likes to claim is a Commonwealth initiative, yet he says it is the responsibility of the states and territories to implement it.

I believe that it is about time that all in this House accept that there is a requirement to actually do something in cities such as Sydney, especially in areas such as Western Sydney. But rather than coming into the House and suggesting that it is this government's or that government's responsibility, we should be trying to work out in a cooperative way how to bring the three tiers of government together in Western Sydney—local, state and Commonwealth—to face up to our shared responsibilities to improve the lifestyle of Western Sydney and to overcome the serious areas of disadvantage that were not touched on by the member for Lindsay in her contribution to the House this week. Yes, lifestyle, Minister, but it is a joint responsibility of the state and federal governments to find a better solution to the problems that exist in Western Sydney and the problems that exist in a number of major cities around Australia. It requires leadership and a real commitment to infrastructure development. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise in the Australian Parliament to express very deep concerns that a Labor member of the Queensland parliament appears to be abandoning the bipartisan approach that ordinarily exists in Australian politics towards our multicultural community. On 7 August 2002, the Labor member for Cleveland in the Queensland parliament, a certain Mr Briskey, used an adjournment speech to criticise the federal Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. Gary Hardgrave. What makes this Labor member's remarks all the more appalling is that he is also a parliamentary secretary with responsibilities for multicultural affairs in Queensland. Having little profile or prominence in the Queensland multicultural community, it is little wonder that the Labor member for Cleveland took the cheap shot opportunity to twist the meaning of the public words of a federal minister into what he thought might be a politically advantageous position.

speech.para: For the benefit of the House, in the relevant Courier-Mail article the federal minister simply spoke of the fact that in modern Australia, where language barriers exist between parents and children, there will invariably be some parents who find exercising their parental authority somewhat difficult and challenging. The minister's point was that such a situation arises in circumstances where English between immigrant parents and their children is at two different levels of fluency. In modern Australia, young migrants very quickly find themselves participating in the fullness of life that our community offers, therefore being able to advance their English far quicker than their parents. It was in this context that the minister made his remarks. There was no reference whatsoever, as the state member for Cleveland—a certain Mr Briskey—claims, that the minister was inciting racial division and attacking certain ethnic communities.

I do not know how familiar the state member for Cleveland is with Vietnamese families, whom regrettably he brought into the debate, but I am certainly happy to compare notes with him at any time, because I know a thing or two about how Vietnamese families function. After all, I am married to a wonderful and beautiful lady of Vietnamese heritage. Moreover, I have known her family for some six years and can completely confirm the spirit and sentiment of the minister's public statements from first-hand experience. I ask the state member for Cleveland whether he is able to compare such experience.

It is important that House of Representatives is aware that there are some politicians who profess to have an expertise in multiculturalism or an interest in the assimilation of new Australians into the broader community, yet really all they are doing is grandstanding for political and media coverage. The member for Cleveland is, I think, one such Labor politician in Queensland who clearly needs to do his homework. I am also disappointed that the member for Mount Ommaney in my federal seat of Ryan has entered the debate and taken an unfortunate and unfounded position.

In the context of multicultural affairs, the role of any member of any parliament in our country is to foster unity and patriotism and especially to reach out to new citizens and make them feel welcome to the great Australian family. I believe that the federal member certainly has the portfolio credentials to represent multicultural Australia. If the state member for Cleveland has any doubts about the federal minister's capacity, all he needs to do is walk down the streets of Sunnybank or Eight Mile Plains and ask the people of Moreton what they think. But from my perspective, as someone who is also a migrant to this country and has a very strong connection with the migrant community in the federal seat of Ryan, I am extremely disappointed that a member of a parliament can falsely accuse and invoke debate on an issue that really should have bipartisan focus.

I encourage the member for Cleveland in the Queensland parliament to do some more homework and, if he wishes to have the confidence of the multicultural community in Queensland, to come to my community. I have not seen him there and I would be very happy to introduce him to Australians of multicultural backgrounds who are great contributors to the story that is Australia. I would welcome him any time. I encourage him to contact my office so that I can promote to him what, from my experience, multiculturalism is all about. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to bring to the attention of the House the Desert Knowledge Symposium, which is taking place in Alice Springs this week—the heart of Australia in more ways than one. This symposium is one of the signature events in the National Year of the Outback calendar and is taking place at Outback Central 2002. Based in my home town of Alice Springs, Outback Central is a 10-day festival of business, science and cultural events that showcases the talent and innovation of the people of the outback. It speaks very highly of the talent and skills within Central Australia and Alice Springs in particular that the Desert Knowledge Symposium has attracted so many high-level local, national and international speakers. They will gather to consider, debate and promote the role of knowledge businesses in the desert regions of Australia and the world.

speech.para: I want to mention several of the desert knowledge projects being developed in Central Australia that have, in many ways, led to this symposium taking place. One of these is the community consultation project known as Alice in 10, which is an initiative of the Northern Territory government. Together with Alice in 10 is the Desert Knowledge Consortium, a group of organisations that came together to develop desert knowledge opportunities in the Alice Springs region. They recently converged with the Alice in 10 project to form Desert Knowledge Australia.

It is an exciting time in Central Australia because we are beginning to appreciate some of the potential in our region that Desert Knowledge Australia is seeking to fulfil. This potential will be realised through using information technology, alternative energy creation and sustainable living applications as the key drivers of the Central Australian economy. This work is being built largely on the efforts and innovation of small, locally based knowledge clusters. It is these groups that the symposium is bringing together, allowing them to share insights and build networks that will progress desert knowledge.

One major achievement has been the proposal for the Cooperative Research Centre. The CRC proposal involves a total budget of more than $94 million over a seven-year program. I commend the Northern Territory government for committing more than $1 million in direct funding to the proposal and $10 million through in-kind contributions. It is an exciting proposal that has drawn support from 12 universities, five Aboriginal organisations, six government agencies, three state and territory governments and five private sector bodies. Clearly, the level of interest the CRC proposal has attracted from across the country is a vote of confidence in the innovation and talent of Central Australia and especially in the potential of the desert knowledge industries.

Another initiative I would like to mention is the Desert People's Centre. Indigenous people from Central Australia have a key role to play in developing and promoting desert knowledge, and they are taking a leadership role in the process. They have knowledge of desert living going back thousands of years and are remarkably generous in their sharing of that knowledge. The Desert People's Centre will work to gather this knowledge for the benefit of future generations and will provide a unique learning environment for all Australians.

A key figure of the desert knowledge movement who deserves mention is Dr Ken Johnson, who has been appointed Senior Executive Officer of Desert Knowledge Australia. Ken has spent almost 25 years in Central Australia and has an immense knowledge of the issues that face a society that is trying to live sustainably in a desert environment. It is also very pleasing to be able to acknowledge the Federal Government's contribution of $50,000 to Desert Knowledge Australia through the Regional Solutions Program, which will provide for another staff member.

The Desert Knowledge Symposium is very important. It will help to bring about the national and international partnerships which will be vital for Central Australia's efforts to export desert knowledge products and technologies to world markets. The symposium will give us a blueprint for action. Hopefully, with the support of public and private sector bodies across the country, the opportunities that are continuing to develop in this field will not be lost. I know that the shadow minister for regional affairs, who is sitting behind me—Blue—is very interested in this proposal.

talk.start.para: —There are two Blueys here!

—Blue 1 and Blue 2. I finish my contribution this evening by paying tribute to a very fine Australian and someone who is leading debate in the Catholic church, Auxiliary Bishop Pat Power. This week he came out in public to talk about the need for the Catholic church to address the issue of celibacy. I have known Bishop Power for over 35 years. He is someone for whom I have a great deal of respect. I know that he has been advancing progressive causes within the Catholic church for decades. It is time that he was properly heard and listened to. I hope that the other bishops and archbishops around Australia listen to what he has to say and promote the ideals which he is trying to promote.

—I rise in this House tonight to first congratulate Bruce Campbell—a great Australian and a great Queenslander—who is Chairman of the Year of the Outback celebrations and whose original idea it was to this year deservedly acknowledge regional and rural towns. As the federal member for Maranoa and as a Year of the Outback ambassador, I have the pleasure of representing many of these outback towns. I feel it is appropriate at this time to make mention of the invaluable contribution these towns add to the wealth and opportunity experienced by many Australians today.

speech.para: The Year of the Outback has been a tremendous experience and journey for a cross-section of Australians. Some regional folk have learnt to enjoy and treasure their own backyards, while our city cousins have joined the droving adventures into the heart of Australia, gaining an insight into the amazing country that is Australia. What is it about this country that has unearthed a desire to explore its outback beauty? Perhaps it is the amazing diversity that extends from the vast open plains, the cracked red earth and almost uninhabitable territory, to the small but thriving rural towns that are adamant about making something of themselves by tapping into a wealth of farming and business opportunities and local initiative.

Celebrations and commemorations have extended throughout the nation in this Year of the Outback. A few months ago, I had the pleasure of being involved in the Great Australian Cattle Drive, which left Birdsville for South Australia on 4 May. On this occasion, Birdsville—which is in the far west of my electorate and well known for its annual Birdsville races—swelled from its modest 100-strong population to well over 1,000 as modern-day drovers saluted their predecessors by droving almost 600 head of cattle in the footsteps of the pioneers through the backblocks of Australia on the edge of the Simpson Desert. This was an unforgettable event which enthralled spectators from all corners of Australia and from overseas.

Earlier this month, the national spotlight turned to our Treasurer, the Hon. Peter Costello, also a Year of the Outback ambassador, as he joined the pilgrimage into western Queensland to see the outback in all its glory. Here, the Treasurer experienced what so many of my constituents are able to enjoy every day—dinner under the canopy of stars, the warm hospitality that is the Australian way and the relentless attempt of its people to survive in today's testing climate.

This trip and in fact this whole year have awakened the national and international senses, with more attention than ever before now focused on outback Australia. As well, many rural communities have been inspired to arrange events to showcase the best their unique homes have to offer. The Year of the Outback was the concept of Bruce Campbell, brought about by his increasing concern with the growing divide between urban and rural communities. Figures show that in 1911 about 43 per cent of Australians lived in rural areas. Today, 85 per cent of the population live in our coastal cities. In spite of the vagaries of the seasons and commodity prices which envelop many of our rural communities, there is still a desire by these families to remain at home and weather the storm in good times and in bad. It is this patriotic passion and sheer grit and determination that has made Australia and its people what they are.

Despite the bitter battle between business and mother nature, industry continues to grow. Yet there is still so much untapped potential in Australia's outback. As this year has been such a success, I believe National Year of the Outback Chairman, Bruce Campbell, and his organisation want to keep the momentum going. The ABC recently reported that Mr Campbell has canvassed this proposition throughout his travels and received total support. People are simply pleased to know that this will be an ongoing process which will be able to build on what has been achieved by communities across Australia this year. The committee wants to continue the theme over the next three years, dedicating time to the themes of knowledge, youth and outback communities. I wholeheartedly support this request, and I believe it is one that the House should consider and support.

talk.start.para: —I would like to congratulate the political editor of the Australian, Mr Dennis Shanahan, for bringing to the attention of the public and indeed the parliament the misrepresentation of Professor Alan Trounson in relation to the things that he has been saying about the potential benefits of embryonic stem cell research. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that I was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs inquiry into human cloning, where we looked at this issue very carefully over two years. No-one on that committee gave the chairman of that committee, Kevin Andrews, more support than I did.

speech.para: During that inquiry, Professor Trounson made it quite clear that he had—indeed, that Australia had—sufficient embryonic stem cell lines for the purposes of his research. Although the minority view formed by the members of the committee condemned how those embryonic stem cells were obtained, we were prepared to live with the fact that he and others might be able to do research in the name of medical science to help people. We were conned and everybody else has been conned. He has certainly conned the Prime Minister and the Premier of New South Wales with this video of the crippled rat walking and linking it to the benefits of embryonic stem cell research. We know now that that is not the case.

I spoke on the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 last Thursday in this House. I understand that tomorrow the bill will be coming back to the House from the Main Committee, where it should never have gone in the first place, because Australia at large is very interested in being able to hear this debate. We are going to deal with amendments—which I hope will be passed by this House—which will outlaw the type of research that Professor Trounson and others want to do in the name of so-called medical science. As I said in my earlier contribution in this House, at the heart of this legislation is a debate that actively promotes the notion of the destruction of an embryo, a human being, in the name of highly speculative medical science.

It is highly speculative that embryonic stem cell research offers any real hope. I think it is cruel to disabled people—particularly people like Christopher Reeve and others who are in wheelchairs—to say that embryonic stem cell research offers some real hope when we know it does not. In fact, the insertion of embryonic stem cells into a spinal column carries a great risk of the cells turning malignant. It is clear from all the scientists who gave evidence to people like Kevin Andrews and me that adult stem cell research—and indeed, in relation to the spinal column, other medical research—offers the most hope for people who are tragically afflicted by disease or injury to the spinal column, like Christopher Reeve.

In my view, embryos should only ever be created for the purposes of creating a human being, never for the purposes of experimentation and research. There have been so-called emotional arguments, which some have said have been the preserve of opponents of this bill. Unfortunately, many scientists in debating this legislation have been quick to build unreasonable or false community expectations about the imminent prospect of new treatments for many terrible conditions. It is a fact that adult stem cell research has had positive results and embryonic stem cell research is just absolutely speculative. Numerous highly esteemed medical scientists who gave evidence before the Andrews inquiry have rightly argued that embryonic stem cells have a great propensity to turn malignant and therefore are not the inevitable source of long-term treatments. I believe ethical science is good science. Embryos should not be treated as spare parts. We were all embryos once and I will be speaking again in the House tomorrow about this. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I require that the debate be extended in order to make some comments.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—There is no need to do so just yet. You can speak for a minute or so.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —I wish to thank the member for Ryan for his excellent address this evening in which he exposed the Labor Party's divisiveness on the issue of community relations. It is indeed very sad to me, as a federal minister and somebody from a very culturally diverse electorate, to see Queensland's Parliamentary Secretary to the Premier and Minister responsible for Multicultural Affairs using the Queensland parliament to make inflammatory comments to cause the entire Vietnamese community distress.
—Order! It being 8 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may continue until 8.10 p.m.

—The state member for Mount Ommaney, Julie Attwood, also woke up long enough to join Darryl Briskey in these comments and, as a result, she also sought to defame members of her own constituency. I think it is a great shame that she should try to bring the Vietnamese community into such disrepute.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. On what basis is the debate being extended?
—The standing orders allow a minister to extend debate by 10 minutes.
—So the adjournment debate is being extended—
—By 10 minutes.
—with your indulgence.
—That is in the standing orders.

—It is also important to note that, on top of what the member for Ryan has observed, the federal member for Rankin has embarked upon a similar program of writing letters to the editor, seeking to distort the facts. The Vietnamese community, though, has one of the highest uptakes of citizenship in this country. They are to be commended for this. Many have made exceptional contributions to Australia and have worked hard to succeed in our society. It is very sad that a senior member of the opposition, the member for Rankin, should also want to generalise comments that I have made regarding language barriers and try to turn them to reflect negatively on such a progressive group within our multicultural society. I would like to read to the House an email from Sang Van To, a member of the Vietnamese community in Brisbane, who emailed me with what he called `a word of thanks'. The email says:

quote.para: Attn: Gary. I just want to send my congrats to you for writing a letter to the local papers of Inala area defending the Vietnamese community ... Normally you see a lot of bad or negative criticisms about the Vietnamese people. But in your short letter you have done us proud by giving that Mt Ommaney politician a serve. Keep up the positive attitude about the Vietnamese community then you will be getting a lot more support than just myself ... Three cheers to you, Gary.

speech.para: As the federal Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs—indeed, as the federal member for Moreton, an ethnically diverse electorate—I believe it is a great pity that others do not also seek to reflect well upon a very progressive and important contributing group like the Vietnamese community. A similar tack has been used by Labor Party people in other places. It was used to politicise the African and Latin American Festival in May in my own electorate, where it was used as a platform for pro-Labor Party political speeches, showing the division that exists within the Queensland government on the matter of refugee policy in this country. The Queensland education minister, Anna Bligh, showed herself to be completely at odds with her premier in the comments that she made publicly that day.

The Australian Labor Party are, as we know, very much out of touch. Most of Australia's six million migrants want to be part of the community and contribute to the building of this great nation. They do not want to be singled out or used as pawns in petty Labor Party style politics. It is also important to know that it does not stop there. This weekend, a Labor Party inspired protest is taking place in Sydney. (Quorum formed) This weekend in Sydney the Australian Labor Party through their member, Mr Talal Yassine, are whipping up a deal of anger in a meeting at the Lakemba mosque. At a time when the Islamic community in Australia is still feeling a sense of vulnerability, the Australian Labor Party have decided to use Mr Yassine, a solicitor who was unsuccessful in his Labor Party preselection for the state seat of Auburn for the by-election in 2001—he lost to Barbara Perry—to try and spread Labor Party propaganda about the government's legislation, which is loosely called the ASIO bill. I think it is disgraceful that emails are being used with attachments that have come directly out of Sussex Street. This effort is simply about trying to create a great deal of divisiveness, a great deal of hurt and a great deal of harm in a community that is very vulnerable. They were not content to have a meeting on 11 August with 160 ALP members and members of a variety of public organisations, including John Faulkner, Professor George Williams, Eva Cox, Cameron Murphy and Talal Yassine speaking on this—

talk.start.para: —Order! The member for Lalor!

—they now wish to try and create a deal of harm and distress amongst members of the Islamic community. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, most Muslims in Australia are contributing members to our community, but if we have people like Talal Yassine doing the work of the Australian Labor Party and circulating reports from their law reform and constitutional forum around in emails—

—The shadow minister opposite is showing, yet again, great contempt for bringing people together. This side is committed to a sense of unity and involvement in Australia in every possible way while those on the other side simply want to smear and cause fear and concern.
—The member for Lalor will cease interjecting.

—The member for Lalor is the shadow minister responsible for immigration matters and she should know better. She should be part of the solution or she is going to continue to be labelled—rightly—as part of the problem. Tonight is all about airing the fact that the Australian Labor Party will at any juncture, on any occasion, attempt to create an even greater sense of vulnerability amongst people in our community who are trying to settle here and be good Australians. The Labor Party stand condemned.

interjection.para: (a) a Bill for an Act to prohibit human cloning and other unacceptable practices associated with reproductive technology, and for related purposes, to be known as the Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002, (incorporating, with associated amendments, the title, enacting formula and Parts 1 and 2 and clauses 56, 61 and 62 and the schedule of the bill as introduced, and an activating clause), and

If the motion that the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 be read a second time is agreed to, for the consideration in detail stage the House then proceed to consider in detail the bill as contained in the form to be made available to Members.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —Last Sunday I had the great pleasure of attending the Sunbury Wine Festival, which clearly is the premier showcase for local wines throughout the region. Not only was I able to visit the established wineries such as Craiglee and Goona Warra—wineries that were established in the 19th century and have been there for almost 150 years—I also had an opportunity to talk with representatives of the Fenton Views Winery, which is a small winery near Clarkefield, the Ray-Monde Winery, the Wildwood Vineyards, the Diggers Rest Vineyard and a number of others. In fact, the Sunbury region is home to 15 boutique wineries now, and they have won their place on Australian tables due to their quality and distinct taste.

speech.para: It was on a warm, sunny Sunday that thousands of visitors from the local area and beyond visited the festival. This year's festival was a turning point. The festival was once a one-day event and now, I am happy to say, this event has turned into a three-day celebration. I should also make mention that the festival kicked off last Friday with the Winemakers' Dinner at Rockbank, at the Witchmount Estate. That, from all accounts, was a wonderful event.

The resurgence of wineries within this region not only enhances the area's appeal but also provides very important economic growth and employment opportunities to the region. Against the backdrop of the collapse of Ansett, this industry's growth is vitally important in Sunbury and also to the Macedon region. Given the proximity to Melbourne's central business district and the allure of beautiful landmarks such as Mount Macedon and Hanging Rock, tourism and hospitality should continue to grow and provide much-needed jobs.

There are 52 vineyards within the Burke electorate, which might be a surprise to some. Last year I wrote to these wineries to inform them of Labor's wine industry policy, particularly with respect to the methods to mitigate the combined impact of the GST and the wine equalisation tax upon cellar door sales. This policy was warmly welcomed by those local businesses. This month my office has resumed dialogue with the local players in the industry, seeking their views on the existing Labor policy currently under review and any further issues they wish to raise. As their local representative and as a member of Labor's wine industry caucus committee, I am keen to contribute to refining Labor's policy in this important area.

talk.start.para: —It is with great sadness that I rise today to advise the House of the death of an outstanding member of the Port Stephens community, Mr Don Waring. Not only was Don Waring a leader in the community but his support for local sporting clubs will never be forgotten. Don Waring's legacy to those in the Nelson Bay area lies mostly in his achievements in sport, sport administration and education.

speech.para: Don and Elizabeth Waring moved to Port Stephens in 1978 and for six years operated the Nelson Bay Preschool on the corner of Dalton and Church streets. In June 1980, Don joined the Tomaree Sports Complex Committee representing the Australian Rules club and pursued the development of a suitable area for the sport to be played. In 1981, Don was the founding president of the Nelson Bay Australian Rules Football Club. He was appointed to the role of secretary-treasurer of the Tomaree Sports Council in March 1981. This position has evolved to its current role as the honorary administrator. Don has also held an executive role within the Nelson Bay Netball Club. During the 1980s he regularly umpired cricket in the district competition and then in the city and the suburban competition, and also assisted with umpiring in the local AFL competition. He umpired over 100 AFL games.

Don fought many battles for local sporting clubs, including one great debate about charging local schools fees for the use of grounds at Nelson Bay Primary School. As usual, he won. In 1992, he was awarded the administrator of the year at the annual Port Stephens Sport Star of the Year awards. In 1996, Don made a significant contribution to the development of the council's sporting clubs loans policy, where council established a $100,000 fund for local sporting clubs to borrow against. Three years later he was a finalist in the Hunter Region Sports Awards in the administrator-volunteer category. And, in 2000—and justifiably so—Don was awarded the Australian Sports Medal for his contribution to sports administration.

In the 20 years that Don has been the honorary administrator we have seen many changes take place. The first financial statement that he tendered totalled an income of only $650, all of which was derived from council subsidies. The 2000-01 financial statement totals an income of just over $28,000, of which the council subsidy is only $1,000. It is a tremendous effort to raise money for local sporting facilities, all of which is returned to the facilities in the Tomaree Peninsula.

It is clear that Don has been the driving force behind the ongoing development and improvement of sporting facilities on the Tomaree Peninsula. From day-to-day upgrades and improvements, his contribution and drive has seen the development of the Tomaree sports complex master plan, and he has been a champion of local sporting organisations. Without identities such as Don Waring, communities such as those on the Tomaree Peninsula would be far worse off. I dare say that his contribution to local sporting causes could not be equalled by anyone in the area. He will be greatly missed, not only for his efforts on the sporting arena but also as a local identity who provided leadership and outstanding community services. Whilst cricket may have their `Don' in Don Bradman, Port Stephens has had its own `Don' in Don Waring. My condolences go to his wife, Elizabeth, and his family at this time. I wish them all well. God bless you, Don Waring. Our community is proud of you. May you rest in peace.

talk.start.para: —Today I want to speak about Nick Brain, a remarkable young man from my electorate of Jagajaga, and the excellent school that he attends, Banksia Secondary College. Nick is an articulate, clever and energetic young fellow. He is the captain of the school and is planning to go to university next year. But what is special about Nick is not only these achievements, important though they are, but also the fact that just three years ago his life was headed down an altogether different path. By the time he was in year 9, Nick's life was in turmoil. His parents had separated, and he was living in a two-bedroom flat with seven other people. In his own words, he had some very bad friends, little money and an unstable home life. Not surprisingly, his studies suffered.

speech.para: Fortunately, Nick's school realised he needed help and was able to provide it. Banksia Secondary College is in an area where it is not uncommon for families to suffer hardship. It recognises the destructive effect instability at home can have on learning, and it believes that providing an education requires much more than providing books, teachers and classrooms. Banksia is a pilot school in the Myer Full Service School Project, which aims to build direct links between schools and organisations that can help students in need such as health services, local clubs and councils. Using its links, Banksia was able to refer Nick to Berry Street, Victoria, a counselling service for young people. It is a connection that has helped Nick turn his life around. Without it he believes he would have dropped out of school, jeopardising his own future and adding to the nation's pool of lost talent.

Nick's experience is a testament to what can be achieved when schools are given the opportunity to take an active interest in their students, not just in their performance at school but also their general welfare. Earlier this month Nick attended the launch in Canberra of a report calling for much greater government investment in education, a report that is called Bridging the gap between the haves and have-nots. It was great to see him at Government House, along with other students, some of whom came from the Queensland area around Ipswich. He is a terrific ambassador for his school, our Nick, and his story highlights the importance of extracurricular support for many students in realising their potential.

This is what makes projects such as full service schools so important. If governments and communities support our teachers and direct efforts towards these schools where disadvantage dominates, we can make a difference to the lives of our children, and that is the task that is very much before us as we develop our critical policies to make sure that students in disadvantaged areas get the opportunities that other people take for granted.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, as you are well aware, I represent Townsville in the national parliament—Townsville, the capital city of Northern Australia but also the capital city of the largest minerals province in the world. I refer to the north-west minerals province, which stretches from the Townsville coastline right out to the Northern Territory border, including the Carpentaria minerals province.

speech.para: I rise to explain to the House the concerns that the mining industry currently has in that province, where there has been a very significant downturn over recent years and a very significant decline in exploration activity. It is finding new resources that, of course, keeps this particular industry going. This decline in exploration resources has seen the loss of perhaps 350,000 jobs, the loss of annual mineral export earnings of more than $30,000 million and the loss of direct revenue to government of more than $8,000 million. As evidence of that decline, the number of listed exploration companies operating out of Townsville has been reduced from around 18 in the mid-1990s to just two in this current year. Geologists, field technicians, IT and administrative staff have all lost their jobs. Local service companies, such as Assay Laboratories, field equipment suppliers and drilling companies, have closed or downsized in response to reduced exploration expenditure. The number of drilling companies has been reduced from around 12 to just four in that time and, I think we all know, many rural towns have suffered a marked economic downturn as exploration activity in the area has slowed or ceased.

What is the solution? There are a number of them. First of all, there needs to be an urgent review of the current native title legislation with respect to land access. It is an awfully costly, uncertain, complex process, which makes it very hard for those seeking to add to Australia's production. We should institute a national register of cultural heritage sites in order to simplify the process of cultural clearance surveys that are required, and the mining industry should not have the responsibility to do this. We should perhaps reintroduce taxation incentives for the mining industry. But, whatever we do, we should also invest in the acquisition of high-quality geoscientific data and provide simple and affordable access to geoscientific data, including government funded research data.

It is extraordinarily important for the government—both the national government and the Queensland government—to recognise what has happened to the exploration industry in the north-west minerals province. So many jobs depend on it, and Australia depends on it.

talk.start.para: —The Sandgate community is in shock following the tragic fire that razed a boarding house on 2nd Avenue. Sadly, three lives were lost in the fire, with a neighbour also losing their life, suffering a heart attack upon witnessing the horrific fire. Our community's thoughts and prayers are with the families and friends of those who lost their lives. In spite of this tragedy, I know the Sandgate community will pull together. An ecumenical service is currently being planned, which will allow local residents to remember those who lost their lives and to pay tribute to the emergency service officers and neighbours who also risked their lives.

speech.para: The aftermath leaves us all wondering how such a loss of life could have been avoided. While investigations are continuing into safety equipment and the cause of the fire, it is also relevant that we look at the housing arrangements for those who rely on boarding house accommodation. Decent housing is vital to the wellbeing of low-income earners, and in most states there is a chronic shortage of decent, affordable housing; we certainly need more. In the context of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, which is currently being reviewed and renegotiated, I hope the government is able to restore funding to this very important area.

Also in the Lilley electorate, we have celebrated the completion of some very important Centenary of Federation projects. An area in the electorate currently being given a new lease of life is Nundah Village, with new business and streetscapes being put in place. Part of that project includes the Nundah Time Line. Funding was provided through the Centenary of Federation grants for 10 bollards, forming part of street art. They are an important reminder of the history of the district and the part Nundah has played in the development of this nation. These bollards represent many different facets of Nundah's history, including the early settlement by German missionaries, the despair of the Great Depression, the triumph of Charles Kingsford-Smith, the success achieved by migrant families, the worker's cottage—representing the hunger of Australians to own their own home—and many other facets. We have also celebrated the opening of the Chermside Historical Precinct, partly funded by a $60,000 Centenary of Federation grant, where the old drill hall from Sandgate was relocated. On Sunday the Milne Bay Library was open to further complement this very important project.

Another Centenary of Federation project was the publication of Pinkenbah: The Fighting Turtles, a history of Pinkenbah State School and district. In the Pinkenbah area we also have a problem, as the Howard government proposes to sell the Meeandah army barracks. This is an irreplaceable asset in the defence of our nation. It is a very important logistics base, ideally situated for key logistical roles in major military mobilisation. The government is flagging its sale and also the location there of a possible detention centre. This is too important a strategic defence site to be flogged off. It would never be able to be replaced. It must remain in public hands.

talk.start.para: —On 18 August 1966, D Company 6RAR was patrolling the area of Long Tan rubber plantation when, at 3.15 p.m., the lead platoon—11th platoon, commanded by Second Lieutenant Gordon Sharp, a national serviceman—encountered a small group of Vietcong, who fled. Patrolling continued until 4.08 p.m., when the main body of the Vietcong 275 Regiment was encountered. The Vietcong attacked vigorously with mortars, rifle fire and machine-gun fire. In the pouring rain, the Australians returned fire and, with the assistance of artillery from the nearby Nui Dat base and support from B Company, the battle swung in favour of the Australians. A far larger force, estimated at some 2,500, was driven off at a cost of 18 Australians killed and 24 wounded.

speech.para: Despite these events being some 36 years ago, the sacrifices of those who fought at Long Tan and throughout the entire Vietnam conflict are still remembered. Those servicemen are remembered not only in our major cities and regional centres but also in hundreds of towns and villages right across the country. I was honoured to receive an invitation to attend the Long Tan Day commemoration at Bowraville from the Bowraville Vietnam Veterans Association. Bowraville is a very small community—a spirited village—in my electorate of Cowper. In a brief but moving ceremony, the community of Bowraville remembered our fallen diggers. I must compliment the efforts of Jim Cameron, President of the Bowraville Vietnam Veterans Association, and Secretary John Glennon for organising the ceremony. I also thank Piper Phil Knight, a veteran from an earlier conflict: Phil is a World War II veteran who, I believe, served in East Timor.

This ceremony is very much a family and community affair, with the honour roll being read by John Glennon's daughter, Sophie, and participation by the local scout troop. The efforts of scout leaders Kieran Dell, Fiona and Robert Grace, Gail and Kevin Smith and their scout group showed the interest of youth in this most important day and the very wide support which this ceremony enjoyed throughout the entire Bowraville community. Also present were the ladies of the local RSL club branch auxiliaries, including well-known personality Betty Boland.

After the ceremony we enjoyed hospitality at the local RSL club, and it was indeed an honour to share this time with the veterans of Bowraville. I am certain that all veterans would be heartened by the commemoration of Long Tan Day across our nation, particularly when you see the depth of community support in our cities and towns, large and small.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: RESEARCH INVOLVING EMBRYOS AND PROHIBITION OF HUMAN CLONING BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Howard:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Whilst we have had a long tradition of caring for the sick in this country, we also have a need to protect those who cannot defend themselves. Human embryos are part of this category and, by sanctioning their destruction, we effectively allow a harmful assault on human life at its most precious moment. I am deeply touched by the real stories of human suffering and disease that have surfaced throughout this debate. No-one can fail to be moved by the powerful stories of human valour and courage in confronting suffering and pain in our young and old.

speech.para: However, the promise by some scientists of a better life, cured of all disease, is an exaggerated proposition. On the available evidence, the promises from scientists of a disease- and illness-free life for those already burdened are unfounded. In fact, some proponents of embryonic stem cell research have gone further and misled members and senators of this parliament. As reported by Dennis Shanahan in the Australian newspaper, the principal lobbyist for embryonic stem cell research, Professor Alan Trounson, showed Canberra politicians a video of a walking rat that had been crippled, claiming that human embryonic stem cells had been injected into the rat which allowed this creature to be cured and to walk. Professor Trounson has admitted that the cells injected into the rat were, in fact, embryonic germ cells taken from aborted foetuses and not from five-day-old fertilised eggs.

Unfortunately, this critical debate has been plagued by individuals and organisations that will say anything to ensure that their side wins. This has included the emotive exploitation of the tragic circumstances of some in our society who are suffering from debilitating diseases. This debate should have been beyond the careers and egos of a handful of talented scientists. Some of the more assiduous promoters of embryonic stem cell research are perpetuating a myth and offering false hope to the most vulnerable members of our community. Those in the medical sciences who peddle an agenda of unlimited ethical boundaries are not seeking to create life or do humanity a good deed. Rather, they seek to destroy life and offer the unfounded possibility of a better life for the sick and vulnerable. Amidst the claims by some scientists of a future free from illness and disease, I believe that balance and caution need to be brought back into this important debate.

Even scientific opinion on this issue is divided. Professor Peter Rathjen, Head of Molecular Biosciences at the University of Adelaide, has cast strong doubt on the alleged benefits of embryonic stem cell research, stating that it is `nonsense that stem cells might be able to cure Alzheimer's'. Professor Gustav Nossal said in the Canberra Times that it would be 10 or 15 years before embryonic stem cell therapies might become available. The jury is out and meaningful evidence is yet to be produced on the supposed amazing cures promoted by the supporters of such research. Yet the dangers associated with embryonic stem cell research are real and, to date, no benefits have been documented. In fact, on the available evidence from attempts to treat Parkinson's disease, the use of embryonic stem cells has proven to be fraught with difficulty.

A more ethical and successful method of stem cell research is through the utilisation of adult stem cells. This approach is free from any of the major ethical dilemmas associated with embryonic stem cell research. Importantly, adult stem cell research has so far produced the most effective and promising success stories in the area of curing human illnesses. Adult stem cell applications are already treating hundreds of thousands of people and offer real hope for those affected by disease and disability. It seems irrational that we are wanting to follow the path of embryonic stem cell research at the very time that the world leaders in this debate, the USA and Germany, are moving in favour of adult stem cell applications and other ethically acceptable alternatives.

Why are some scientists intent on killing human embryos instead of channelling efforts towards successful and ethical research areas? Adult stem cell applications already have the runs on board and the research on adult stem cells has produced gratifying results. These results are not perfect as yet, but some of the successful applications of adult stem cell research include restoration of vision and stabilisation of multiple sclerosis. I warmly welcome the news published in Nature journal concerning the medical breakthrough in the United States on adult stem cell research. This news is clear evidence that adult stem cell research is capable of achieving and working towards a satisfactory treatment for many of our diseases and medical ailments.

Contrary to popular opinion, this is not a debate about religion pitted against science; that was a debate that occurred in the 18th century, when science was the great antithesis of religion. Rather, this is a debate about the merits of a proposal that will give scientists unfettered access to our most precious asset—human life. What sort of society do we create when we afford dignity and rights to some members and not to others?

My position to vote against this bill has been vindicated by those in my electorate who have taken the time to write, phone and email my office thanking me for my stance. In my nine months as a federal member of this parliament, I have received more correspondence on this issue than on any other. There are significant community concerns about the passage of the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 and I believe that through its passage we will take a backward step as a society. As I said before, research that might save lives is superfluous if it destroys life in the process.

I believe that medical science should be concerned with nurturing and protecting human life. Through the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 embryos are to be sacrificed for corporate and scientific gain, with little acknowledgment of the ethical dilemmas associated with such a process. I am unable to sanction the destruction of human embryos for scientific experimentation and endorse the subsequent devaluing of human life. I am sceptical about the effectiveness of the intended safeguards in this bill.

Forgive my cynicism, but scientists are not immune from ordinary human weaknesses and are not beyond the temptation to pursue experimentation beyond the guidelines this bill establishes. We have already seen the scientists leading the charge in favour of experimentation on human embryos spectacularly misinforming parliamentarians about the effectiveness of such research. I do not accept the argument that if one supports IVF it necessarily follows that one should support research into embryos. IVF is about giving families the opportunity to enjoy the pleasures of having children. Research on embryonic stem cells is about the deliberate destruction of embryos. If this bill is passed, a new class of human life is created—that is, embryos that are at the immediate disposal of scientists.
